cyclone.name: IRMA
cyclone.current_location: about 255 miles (410 km) ESE of Grand Turk Island
cyclone.trajectory: Irma is expected to continue WNW across the Turks and Caicos and Bahamas, turn toward the Florida peninsula this weekend, then curve northward inland across Georgia and the Carolinas.

weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida east coast, Georgia and South Carolina coasts are within the 4–5-day forecast cone.
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm winds are possible by late Sunday night or Monday with a 56 % chance of 34-kt winds and up to a 26 % chance of 50-kt winds; brief hurricane-force gusts can’t be ruled out if the core tracks inland just west of the port.
weather_observation.storm_surge: Onshore flow north of the storm could push 3–6 ft of water above ground along the Georgia coast, including the Savannah River entrance.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands of heavy rain associated with Irma may produce 4–8 inches, locally higher, leading to flash flooding in coastal Georgia.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Isolated tornadoes in outer rainbands; prolonged port closures and navigation restrictions due to high seas and debris.
